article_text:
Entrepreneurs on the verge of an initial public offering often face a stark fact: The company has policies that investors won’t like.

So, what do they do? In some cases, they try to hide those rough spots by making their official documents hard to understand.

That’s the conclusion of a recent study that examined IPO-related documents of 1,655 companies that went public between 1995 and 2011 and analyzed how the companies...

twitter.description: A study finds that firms cover up policies investors won’t like with obfuscation and jargon—and often profit from it
twitter.title: How Startups Hide Investor-Unfriendly Practices
